description: From Middle English removen, from Anglo-Norman remover, removeir, from Old French remouvoir, from Latin removēre, from re- + movēre (“to move”). Displaced native Old English āfierran.

entries.meaning: (cooking, now chiefly historical) A dish served to replace an earlier one during a meal; a part of a new course.
examples: A supper brings up the rear, not forgetting the introductory luncheon, almost equalling in removes the dinner.

entries.meaning: (Britain) (at some public schools) A division of the school, especially the form prior to last
A step or gradation (as in the phrase "at one remove")
Distance in time or space; interval.
(figurative, by extension) Emotional distance or indifference.
(dated) The transfer of one's home or business to another place; a move.
examples: It is an English proverb that three removes are as bad as a fire.

entries.meaning: The act of resetting a horse's shoe.
examples: His horse wanted two removes; your horse wanted nails

verbs.description: remove (third-person singular simple present removes, present participle removing, simple past and past participle removed)

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To move something or someone from one place to another, especially to take away.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, formal) To replace a dish within a course.
(transitive) To discard, set aside, especially something abstract (a thought, feeling, etc.).
(intransitive, archaic) To change one's residence or place of business; to move.
examples: Shortly after this, my father removed, and settled in the same county, about ten miles above Greenville.

entries.meaning: To dismiss or discharge from office.
